column3: had agreed to go to the White Mountains with the others. She admitted
column5: that she'd probably have a good time
column7: but still her heart clung to "The Pebbles
column8: as they called their seashore home, and she silently rebelled when she thought of Camilla
column9: her swift little electric runabout.Patty drove her own car, and she never tired of spinning along the shore roads, or inland through the pine groves and laurel jungles. She had become acquainted with many young people, both cottagers and hotel guests, and the outlook for a pleasant summer and fall at Spring Beach was all that could be desired from her point of view. But before they left the city in the spring, Patty had known that Nan preferred mountain localities and had agreed to the seashore house for her sake; so, now, it was Patty's turn to give up her preference for Nan's. And she was going to do it,—oh, yes,—she was going to do it cheerfully and even gaily.
